right so grief is the natural healing

it's interesting in that um in the case

not only an internal natural healing

is but there's also a social healing

someone has lost someone um we naturally
even if we certainly if they're someone
close to us we're going to be there for

early on in their homes um bring them

they may really need to be treated um

is a natural healing process from our
point of view but but it it sort of and
it sort of never really completely ends
after you lose someone very very close
so what happens to it though is it
becomes it it evolves over time right so
in the beginning we call it acute grief
because it's a it's very it's kind of
very inflamed it's it's like um and it's
very dominant and it's a a very intense
reaction and then over time it
progresses to a place where it's much
more in the background but it's still
there so for example if you you know if
you the person that you went to visit
you know that had the acute grief if you
went back and visited that person let's
say five years later um and you said to
them you know you you first of all you
would not expect them to be preoccupied
with the loss anymore right you would
expect them to be themselves again they
they wouldn't be um crying all the time
they wouldn't be only thinking about the
person who died they'd be engaging with
you probably totally other topics but
then if you said to them you know I was
thinking about this person who died the
other day and um I was remembering some
story you wouldn't be surprised if they
if they got kind of quiet and and maybe

you started to talk about this person
that they loved very much who gone in
fact you'd be pretty shocked if they
said who was that I don't think I
remember that person you wouldn't you
wouldn't expect that at all so that's
the
natural sort of trajectory if you think
about it of um of loss and and how upset
that person will get five years from now
is very variable it really depends on
who died and how you know how close you
really were to them and what's going on
in your life otherwise and all kinds of
things like that so what happens when
you get complicated grief and and um the
answer to that is that instead of that
natural process
unfolding um so that the the thoughts
and the memories kind of recede a little
bit into the background sometimes we we
think of this as begin to reside in your
heart instead of center stage in your
mind instead of that happening um the
person actually gets kind of sidetracked
in the in the mour process such that
they start to kind of ruminate over
something related to the death very
often some way that they think they
could have prevented this death so the
person will start to think um you know
if only I'd gotten this person to the

diagnosed sooner maybe they wouldn't
have you know they would have been able
to be cured or you know sometimes it's
focused on the medical profession why
didn't the doctor misdiagnose this

focused on
that sometimes it's um related to I I
can't
I can't manage without this person the
person instead of thinking about kind of
how how how they are going to manage
they get sidetracked by thinking I can't
possibly manage basically telling
themselves that so there are the
complications that derail grief include
these kinds of repetitive we call them
ruminating kinds of thoughts or also um
there's a lot of pain emotional pain of
course in the acute grief process and
some people are kind of frightened of
those emotions or even frightened of of
the thought of the person really being
gone and so they try to avoid it so they
try to avoid things that trigger the
emotions and they try to avoid thinking

the person having died and so that
avoidance is also a complication it
becomes a complication because it
doesn't it it interferes with the

terms with the death that has to go on
